message.content: We refer to the CDC website on immunizations for help. The patient’s history of severe allergic reaction to previous shots and food suggests a possible allergy to some components of the vaccine. Intramuscular influenza vaccine contains egg protein, which can cause an allergic reaction in some individuals with egg allergy, so it is not recommended for this patient. The MMR and varicella vaccines are produced in chick embryo cell culture but have been shown to be safe for most children with egg allergy. The intranasal influenza vaccine is also not recommended for children under 2 years of age.

We refer to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) website for help. The patient’s history of severe allergic reactions suggests that the intramuscular influenza vaccine should not be given. However, the MMR and varicella vaccines are still recommended for the patient. The intranasal influenza vaccine should also be avoided in this patient as it contains eggs, which the patient has shown to be allergic to.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of severe allergic reactions, which is a contraindication for receiving the intramuscular influenza vaccine. All other options are either recommended or not contraindicated based on the patient’s history.

We refer to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidelines for immunizations for help. The patient’s history suggests a potential severe allergic reaction, so the intramuscular influenza vaccine (option B) is not recommended. The MMR vaccine (option A) contains gelatin that may cause an allergic reaction but it is not contraindicated in patients with a history of severe allergy to gelatin. The varicella vaccine (option C) contains neomycin, which may cause an allergic reaction but it is not a contraindication either. The intranasal influenza vaccine (option D) is contraindicated in children under 2 years old, regardless of their allergy history.

We refer to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidelines on immunization. The patient’s history of severe allergic reactions to certain foods indicates a potential risk for anaphylaxis following immunization, particularly with vaccines that contain similar food allergens. The intramuscular influenza vaccine contains egg protein, which is a common allergen. Therefore, it is not recommended for this patient. The other vaccines listed do not contain common food allergens and are recommended for routine immunization.

We refer to CDC guidelines for help. The patient’s history of severe allergic reaction to certain foods and vaccines indicate a potential for anaphylaxis, and the IM influenza vaccine is contraindicated in patients with a history of severe allergic reactions to any vaccine component or following a previous dose of any influenza vaccine. The other vaccines listed are not contraindicated in this patient based on the available information.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history suggests he may have an allergy to certain foods, so the intramuscular influenza vaccine should be avoided as it may trigger an allergic reaction. The MMR vaccine and the varicella vaccine are not contraindicated in patients with allergies, and the intranasal influenza vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine that is not a preferred option for children under 2 years old, regardless of allergies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of severe allergic reactions to certain foods and vaccinations, making him a high-risk patient for adverse reactions to intramuscular influenza vaccination. Intranasal influenza vaccination is a potential alternative. Measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine, Varicella vaccine are typically safe and recommended for children.

We refer to the CDC recommendations on immunizations for help. The patient’s history of severe allergic reactions to vaccinations and certain solid foods makes intramuscular influenza vaccine not recommended. The other options are either not contraindicated or not yet due at 12 months of age.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the patient’s history of severe allergic reactions to certain foods and shots, it is important to avoid giving any vaccine with a potential allergen. The intramuscular influenza vaccine may contain egg protein, which can trigger an allergic reaction in some patients. Therefore, it is not recommended for this patient. The MMR vaccine, varicella vaccine, and intranasal influenza vaccine do not contain egg protein and are safe for the patient to receive.
